column4: You'll likely have to register your DNS servers with your registrar first - giving them IP addresses to match up to two hostnames, or something along those lines
ok I'll call them and ask about that. Thanks
who is your registrar?
ah, in that case, I can't help you out much with dealing with them
my website needs to create/delete subdomains on the fly, so I though I run my own DNS on a random domain I've made. So I can have blabla.blala.mydomain.com
You might want to think about using a wildcard subdomain instead of creating DNS records for each subdomain you create.
creating a dns record for dynamically created subdomains, even with low TTL values, they can still be cached for longer than you want by some ISPs DNS caching servers
hmm, interesting. Good to know
You can use apache's mod_rewrite to rewrite requests for the subdomains to something like yoursite.com/subdomain/
apache is thus out of the picture
You could use apache's mod_proxy :)
does it work with other protocols than http and such?
if so I'll read up on it. Just so I don't missunderstand u
No, unfortunately, mod_proxy doesn't handle other protocols
then the only way to go is using DNS records with low TLS and no cache if it works
How often does the DNS records change?
and do those changes need to be reflected instantaneously for ALL users?
it won't change often. But I will create new ones for my customers quite often. They will stick
Oh, if you're just creating them often, and not changing where a certain CNAME points, then your solution should work
they won't change in theory. But when a new client get's a subdomain, I want it to work instantly.
when I create a subdomain, will it be visible instantly?
I see no reason why not, but if you know? ^^
should be instant, pretty much
great
